title: Doudou Diène
text:
Doudou Diène (born 1941) is a <a href="Senegal">Senegal</a>ese jurist. He was <a href="United%20Nations%20Special%20Rapporteur">United Nations Special Rapporteur</a> on contemporary forms of racism, racial discrimination, xenophobia and related intolerance from 2002–2008.
Education.
Diène holds a <a href="law">law</a> degree from the <a href="Caen%20University">University of Caen</a> (<a href="France">France</a>), a doctorate in <a href="public%20law">public law</a> from the <a href="University%20of%20Paris">University of Paris</a>, a diploma in political science from the <a href="Institut%20d%27Etudes%20Politiques%20de%20Paris">Institut d'Études Politiques</a> in <a href="Paris">Paris</a>, and an Honorary Degree of Doctor of Laws degree from the University of the West Indies (Cave Hill, Barbados)
Titles.
Between 1972 and 1977 he served as Senegal's deputy representative to <a href="UNESCO">UNESCO</a>. In 1977, he joined the UNESCO secretariat, where he held several positions including Director of the Division of Inter-cultural Projects. He was appointed <a href="United%20Nations%20special%20rapporteur">Special Rapporteur</a> for racism-related topics by the <a href="United%20Nations%20Commission%20on%20Human%20Rights">United Nations Commission on Human Rights</a> in August 2002, replacing <a href="Maurice%20Glele-Ahanhanzo">Maurice Glele-Ahanhanzo</a> of <a href="Benin">Benin</a> and serving until July 2008 when he was succeeded by <a href="Githu%20Muigai">Githu Muigai</a> (Kenya).
In 2005, the UN assigned him to investigate violence in <a href="Togo">Togo</a> and racism in <a href="Japan">Japan</a>. He also investigated, as an independent expert, human rights violations during the <a href="2010%E2%80%932011%20Ivorian%20crisis">2010–2011 Ivorian crisis</a>, and later in <a href="Gaza%20strip">Gaza strip</a> in 2014 to 2018. 
In 2007, Diène denounced the words of French President <a href="Nicolas%20Sarkozy">Nicolas Sarkozy</a> during his "<a href="Nicolas%20Sarkozy%20Dakar%20address">Dakar speech</a>" and spoke of an attempt to, "scientifically legitimize historical stereotypes of the construction of racism".
In 2011, he was appointed Independent Expert on the situation of human rights in <a href="C%C3%B4te%20d%27Ivoire">Côte d'Ivoire</a>.
Doudou Diène has been chairman of the <a href="United%20Nations">United Nations</a> commission of inquiry on <a href="Burundi">Burundi</a> since February 2018.
